item.title: pandas: Dataframes
item.dc:creator: Patrick Ho
item.description:
In [1]:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

pd.__version__
Out[1]:
'0.23.1'

Create¶

In [ ]:
# Create empty dataframe
df = pd.DataFrame()

# Create from CSV
df = pd.read_csv('./data/file.csv')

# Create from random values
df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(5, 3),
                  columns=['col1', 'col2', 'col3'])

# Create from dictionary
df = pd.DataFrame({'col1': ['A', 'B', 'C'],
                   'col2': [1, 2, 3]})

# Create from Series
col1 = pd.Series(['A', 'B', 'C'])
col2 = pd.Series([1, 2, 3])

df = pd.concat([col1, col2], axis=1)
df.columns = ['col1', 'col2']

Index¶

In [9]:
df = pd.DataFrame({'col1': [3, 1, 2],
                   'col2': ['A', 'B', 'C'],
                   'col3': [8, 5, 7],
                   'col4': [True, False, True]})
df
Out[9]:
col1 col2 col3 col4
0 3 A 8 True
1 1 B 5 False
2 2 C 7 True
In [10]:
# Set index - move columns 'left' to become an index
df = df.set_index(['col1', 'col3'])  # can have multiple indexes
df
Out[10]:
col2 col4
col1 col3
3 8 A True
1 5 B False
2 7 C True
In [11]:
# Reset index - move columns back to the 'right'
df = df.reset_index('col1')
df
Out[11]:
col1 col2 col4
col3
8 3 A True
5 1 B False
7 2 C True

Subset¶

Select Columns¶

In [ ]:
# Using column name
df['col 1!']          # if column name has spaces or special characters
df[['col1', 'col2']]  # multiple columns

# Using dot notation
df.col1

# Using loc function
df.loc[:, ['col1','col2']]

Select Rows¶

By column value¶

Must use bitwise operators '&' (AND) and '|' (OR)

In [ ]:
# Select rows on condition
df[df['col'] == 5]
df[(df['col'] > 5) & (df['col'] < 10)]

# Select rows with nulls in specified column
df[df['col'].isnull()]

# Select rows without nulls in specified column
df[df['col'].notnull()]
By index label¶

Selecting rows by index is faster than '=='. Even faster if already sorted by index.

In [ ]:
df.loc[0]          # row with index label 0
df.loc[1:3]        # rows with index label 1 to 3 inclusive
df.loc['A']        # rows with index label 'A'
df.loc[['A','B']]  # rows with index label 'A' or 'B'
df.loc['A', 15]    # rows where first index is 'A' and second index is 15
By position¶
In [ ]:
df.iloc[0]         # first row
df.iloc[1:5]       # rows at position 1 to 4

Select Columns and Rows¶

In [ ]:
# col1 and col2, rows where col3<4
df[['col1','col2']][df['col3']<4]

# col1 and col2, rows with index label 'A' or 'B'
df[['col1','col2']].loc[['A', 'B']]

# col1 and col2, rows at position 1 to 3
df[['col1','col2']].iloc[1:4]

Sort¶

In [ ]:
# Sort by value ascending
df.sort_values(by='col1')

# Sort by value descending
df.sort_values(by='col1', ascending=False)
In [15]:
# Sort by index
df = pd.DataFrame({'col1': [3, 1, 2],
                   'col2': [1, 2, 3]}).set_index('col1')
df.sort_index()
Out[15]:
col2
col1
1 2
2 3
3 1

Append¶

In [ ]:
# Keep duplicate rows
pd.concat([df1, df2])

# Drop duplicate rows
pd.concat([df1, df2]).drop_duplicates()

# Drop duplicate rows based on specified columns, keeping first occurrence
pd.concat([df1, df2]).drop_duplicates(subset=['col1', 'col2'])

# Drop duplicate rows based on specified columns, keeping last occurrence
pd.concat([df1, df2]).drop_duplicates(subset=['col1', 'col2'], keep='last')

Join¶

In [ ]:
# Column to column inner join
pd.merge(df1, df2,
         left_on='coll', right_on='colr',
         how='inner',
         suffixes=['', '_r'])  # column name suffixes for duplicates

# Index to index left join
pd.merge(df1, df2,
         left_index=True, right_index=True,
         how='left',
         suffixes=['', '_r'])

# Column to index outer join
pd.merge(df1, df2,
         left_on='coll', right_index=True,
         how='outer',
         suffixes=['', '_r'])

Reshape¶

Pivoting¶

In [125]:
df = pd.DataFrame({'foo': ['one', 'one', 'one', 'two', 'two', 'two'],
                   'bar': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'A', 'B', 'C'],
                   'baz': [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6],
                   'zoo': ['x', 'z', 'x', 'x', 'z', 'z']})
df
Out[125]:
foo bar baz zoo
0 one A 1 x
1 one B 2 z
2 one C 3 x
3 two A 4 x
4 two B 5 z
5 two C 6 z
In [33]:
# Pivot - Transpose tall to wide
df.pivot(index='foo', columns='bar', values='baz')
Out[33]:
bar A B C
foo
one 1 2 3
two 4 5 6
In [46]:
# Pivot - Transpose tall to wide with aggregation of values
df.pivot_table(index='foo', columns='zoo', values='baz', aggfunc=np.sum)
Out[46]:
zoo x z
foo
one 4 2
two 4 11

Stacking/Unstacking¶

Dataframes require both left and top index. If you stack/unstack too much, it will become a Series.

In [72]:
df = pd.DataFrame({'foo': ['one', 'one', 'two', 'two'],
                   'bar': ['A', 'B', 'A', 'B'],
                   'baz': [1, 3, 5, 7],
                   'zoo': [2, 4, 6, 8]}).set_index(['foo', 'bar'])
df
Out[72]:
baz zoo
foo bar
one A 1 2
B 3 4
two A 5 6
B 7 8
In [74]:
# Move innermost left index 'up' to innermost top index - Wider
df_unstacked = df.unstack()
df_unstacked
Out[74]:
baz zoo
bar A B A B
foo
one 1 3 2 4
two 5 7 6 8
In [75]:
# Move innermost top index 'down' to innermost left index - Taller
df_unstacked.stack()
Out[75]:
baz zoo
foo bar
one A 1 2
B 3 4
two A 5 6
B 7 8

item.title: Python: Dictionaries
item.dc:creator: Patrick Ho
item.description:
Create¶

In [ ]:
# Init empty dictionary
empty_dict = {}

# Init dictionary with key:value pairs
a_dict = {'Alice':30, 'Bob':35, 'Chris':28, 'Dave':'N/A'}

# Init dictionary using dict()
a_dict = dict(Alice=30, Bob=35, Chris=28, Dave='N/A')

Inspect¶

In [ ]:
# Number of key-value pairs in dictionary
len(a_dict)

# Check if key is in dictionary
'a' in a_dict
any(x in a_dict for x in ['a', 'b'])  # check if any items in dictionary
all(x in a_dict for x in ['a', 'b'])  # check if all items in dictionary

# Check if value is in dictionary
'a' in a_dict.values()

# List of keys
a_dict.keys()

# List of values
a_dict.values()

# List of key-value pairs (as tuples)
a_dict.items()

Access¶

In [ ]:
# Lookup single value by key
a_dict['Bob']
a_dict.get('Frank')               # returns None
a_dict.get('Frank', 'Not Found')  # returns 'Not Found'

Add items to the dictionary¶

In [ ]:
# Add new item
a_dict['Ed'] = 49

Edit items in the dictionary¶

In [ ]:
# Edit existing item
a_dict['Dave'] = 42

# Assignment creates reference, not a copy!
a_dict = {'a':1, 'b':2, 'c':3}
b_dict = a_dict
a_dict['a'] = 99  # both values for 'a' and 'b' will be 99

Remove items from the dictionary¶

In [ ]:
# Delete item
del a_dict['Alice']

# Remove all items leaving empty dictionary
a_dict.clear()

# Delete dictionary
del a_dict

Sort¶

Dictionaries have no order, can either:

  • Create a sorted representation as a list
  • Use OrderedDict
In [ ]:
import operator
import collections

# Sorted by value, represent as a list of tuples
a_dict = {'a':3, 'b':5, 'c':2, 'd':8}
a_dict_sorted = sorted(a_dict.items(), key=operator.itemgetter(1))

# Store as OrderedDict
a_dict_ordered = collections.OrderedDict(a_dict_sorted)

Combine¶

In [ ]:
# Add a dictionaries key-value pairs to another with dupes removed
a_dict.update(dict2)

item.title: Python: Error Handling
item.dc:creator: Patrick Ho
item.description:
Error Handling¶

  • List of error types: https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html
In [1]:
try:
    numerator = int(input('Enter numerator: '))
    denominator = int(input('Enter denominator: '))
    result = numerator/denominator
    print(result)
except ValueError:
    print('No value entered')
except ZeroDivisionError:
    print('Divide by zero')
except Exception as e:
    print('Other error: ', e)

Enter numerator: 1
Enter denominator: 0
Divide by zero

item.title: Python: Files
item.dc:creator: Patrick Ho
item.description:
Reading¶

  • 'r' reading
  • 'r+' reading and writing
  • 'rb' read binary file
In [ ]:
# Reading line by line
f = open('file.txt', 'r')

line1 = f.readline()  # read a line, append \n, move pointer to next line
line2 = f.readline()
line3 = f.readline()

f.close()


# Reading lines with for loop
f = open('file.txt', 'r')

for line in f:
    print(line)

f.close()


# Reading files with set buffer size
f = open('file.txt', 'r')

while len(buf)>0:
    buf = f.read(20)  # 20 bytes at a time
    
f.close()

Writing¶

  • 'w' writing, creates/overwrites
  • 'a' appending, creates/appends
  • 'wb' write binary file
In [ ]:
# Writing line by line
f = open('file.txt', 'a')

f.write('Line 1\n')
f.write('Line 2\n')

f.close()

Deleting¶

In [ ]:
remove('file.txt')

Renaming¶

In [ ]:
rename('old.txt', 'new.txt')

OS Commands¶

In [ ]:
import os

# Check if file already exists
if os.path.exists('file.txt'):
    print('File exists!')
else:
    print('File does not exist!')

item.title: Python: Functions
item.dc:creator: Patrick Ho
item.description:
Functions¶

  • Variables defined within function are not available outside function
  • Variables within function overrides global variables of same name
In [1]:
def multiplyByTwo(val):
    result = val * 2
    return result

multiplyByTwo(3)
Out[1]:
6

Main Function¶

  • If running script as main:
    • __name__ will be set to __main__
    • Following code will execute
  • If importing as module:
    • __name__ will be something else
    • Following code will not execute
In [ ]:
# Basic
def main():
    # code

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
In [ ]:
# With arguments - argv[0] refers to python script, argv[1] is first argument etc.
import sys

def main(argv):
    print(str(argv))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main(sys.argv)

item.title: Python: Lists
item.dc:creator: Patrick Ho
item.description:
Create¶

In [ ]:
# Init empty list
empty_list = []

# Init list with values
a_list = [5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 'dog']

Inspect¶

In [ ]:
# Number of items in list
len(a_list)

# Check if item is in list
'a' in a_list
any(x in a_list for x in ['a', 'b'])  # check if any items in list
all(x in a_list for x in ['a', 'b'])  # check if all items in list

Access¶

In [ ]:
# Access single item
a_list[0]      # first item
a_list[-2]     # second last item

# Access slice of items
a_list[:3]     # first 3 items
a_list[4:]     # 5th item until last
a_list[-3:]    # last 3 items
a_list[2:6]    # items at index 2 to 5 (6-1)
a_list[2:8:2]  # index steps of 2

Adding to the list¶

In [ ]:
# Add item to end of list
a_list.append('a')

# Insert item to a specified index position
a_list.insert(3, 'a')

Edit items in the list¶

In [ ]:
# Overwrite existing item
a_list[10] = 1000

# Assignment creates reference, not a copy!
a = [1,2,3]
b = a
a[0] = 99  # both a[0] and b[0] will be 99

Remove items from the list¶

In [ ]:
# Remove item from list by index
del a_list[0]    # delete first item
del a_list[3:5]  # delete items at index 3 to 5

# Remove item from list by value
a_list.remove('a')

# Retrieve item from list and remove it
a_list.pop()   # last item
a_list.pop(2)  # item at index 2

Sort¶

In [ ]:
# Sort list in-place
a_list.sort()              # default ascending
a_list.sort(reverse=True)  # descending

# Sort into new list and retain original unsorted list
new_list = sorted(orig_list)

# Reverse order
a_list.reverse()

Combine¶

In [ ]:
# Concatenate
a_list + b_list
a_list.extend(b_list)  # alternative method, will update a_list

# Duplicate and append
a_list * 3  # i.e. a_list + a_list + a_list

item.title: Python: Modules
item.dc:creator: Patrick Ho
item.description:
Modules¶

  • To create own module, save code with .py extension
In [ ]:
# Import module, reference using module name
import sys

# Import module, reference using another name
import pandas as pd

# Import only parts of module
from sklearn import datasets

# Append module location path if it doesn't exist
if '/module_directory' not in sys.path:
    sys.path.append('/module_directory')

item.title: Python: OS Interaction
item.dc:creator: Patrick Ho
item.description:
OS Interaction¶

In [1]:
# Run command line programs
import subprocess

command = ['which', 'python']
try:
    print(subprocess.check_output(command))
except:
    print('Could not run command')

b'/home/pat/miniconda3/bin/python\n'
In [ ]:
# Delete file
import os

os.remove('file.txt')

item.title: Python: Print
item.dc:creator: Patrick Ho
item.description:
Print¶

In [1]:
print('Hello', 'world!')  # adds space by default

print('Hello', 'world!', sep='')  # no space between

print('''Line 1
Line 2
Line 3''')  # triple quotes to use multiple lines

print(r'\n \t')  # raw string, doesn't interpret escape characters

# Formatting with %
print('String is %s, Integer is %5d, Float is %4.2f' % ('Test', 123, 3.14159))

# Formatting with format() - {index:format}
print('String is {0:s}, Integer is {1:5d}, Float is {2:4.2f}'.format('Test', 123, 3.14159))

Hello world!
Helloworld!
Line 1
Line 2
Line 3
\n \t
String is Test, Integer is   123, Float is 3.14
String is Test, Integer is   123, Float is 3.14

item.title: Python: Strings
item.dc:creator: Patrick Ho
item.description:
Create¶

In [ ]:
a_string = 'abc'
b_string = 'xyz'

# Convert to string
c_string = str(2.1)

Inspect¶

In [ ]:
# Number of characters in string
len(a_string)

# Check if all characters...
a_string.isalpha()  # are alphabetic
a_string.isdigit()  # are digits
a_string.isalnum()  # are alphanumeric
a_string.islower()  # are lowercase, ignores digits/punctuation
a_string.isupper()  # are uppercase, ignores digits/punctuation
a_string.isspace()  # are whitespaces, includes \n and \t
a_string.istitle()  # are titlecased, i.e. first letter of each word is cap

# Unique strings only
string_list.unique()

Find substrings¶

In [ ]:
# Number of substring occurrences
a_string.count('sub')

# Position of substring
a_string.index('sub')  # returns ValueError if not found
a_string.find('sub')   # same, but returns -1 if not found

# Check if starts/ends with substring
a_string.startswith('sub')
a_string.startswith(('foo', 'bar'))  # can specify tuple of possible matches
a_string.endswith('sub')

# Replace substrings
a_string.replace('old', 'new')
a_string.replace('old', 'new', 3)  # replace first 3 occurrences only

Cleaning¶

In [ ]:
# Convert all characters to upper/lowercase
a_string.upper()
a_string.lower()

# Remove leading and trailing characters
a_string.strip()       # whitespace
a_string.strip('ab ')  # remove leading/trailing 'a', 'b', ' '

Combining¶

In [ ]:
# Concatenate
a_string + ' ' + b_string

# Join up a list/tuple/string with specified separator in between
sep = '-'
list1 = ['aaa', 'bbb', 'ccc']
a_string = 'Hello World!'
sep.join(list1)    # 'aaa-bbb-ccc'
sep.join(a_string)  # 'H-e-l-l-o- -W-o-r-l-d-!'

Splitting¶

In [ ]:
# Split up string into a list of substrings
a_string.split()        # use space as separator
a_string.split(',')     # use comma as separator
a_string.split(' ', 2)  # use space as separator, only first 2 splits

# Split up string by lines
a_string.splitlines()               # use line breaks as separator
a_string.splitlines(keepends=True)  # keep line break characters
